The committee appointed by the resolution os,he
Grand Chapter, on the affair OF William Morgan,
respectfully report:


That they have attended to the duties assigned
them, and from the highly agtated and in6amed
state of public feeling this subject, and from the
false and undeservcd imputstiops which have been
thrown upon freemasons. and the masonic order
generally your committee deem it proper that this
Grand Chapter should make public expression of
its sentiments in relation to the affair alluded TO.
Your committee, as expressive of their views on this
subject, would offer for the consideration of the
Grand Chapter, the following preamble and resolu-
ton.


Whereas. the rights ofpersona liberty and secu-
rity are guaranteed by the free contribution under
which we, the members Of this Grand Chapter, in
common with the rest Of our fellow citizens, have
the happiness to live: And whereas we esteem the
preservation Of these rights Of vital importanee 70
The perpetuity and full enjoyment Of the blessings
NEW YORK GRAND CHAPTER,

our republican institutions - Ard whereas the COM
munty has lately Witnessed a violation Of the same
under the alleged pretext of the masonic name and
sanction, in the case Of William Morgan: And
whereas the principles of our ancient and honorable
fraternity contain nothing which in the slightest de-
gree justify or authorize such proceedings but,
on the contrary, do in all their tenets and cereno-
nies, encourages and inculcate just submission to
the laws, the enjoyment Of equal rights by every
individual, and high and elevated spirit OF person.
al as well as national independence:


Therefore Resolred, by this Grand Chapter, that
we its members, individually and body, do
dscaim all knowledge or appreciation Of the said
proceedings. in relation to the abduction OF the said
William Morgan and that we disapprove Of he
same violation Of the majesty Of the laws, and
infringement, Of the rights Of personal liberty,
cured every citizen Of our free and happy repub-
lie.


A true extract from the minutes the Grand
Royal Arch Chapter the state of New.fork.


]. o. COLE, .sec'ry
y Wilson, No. 1O5, Market Street.

John Anderson-we supposed it was. He then
addressed a letter to Gen Washington, in which
he declared his name and rank-it was John Andre,
Of the rank of major, acting adjutant general to the
British army. The fate Of the poor fellow is ell
known--I saw him executed. have frequently
heard it said he agiated, hc.-t is not correct,
at least Tar as il could be seen. He met his death
like q man, and died like soldier, the death Of a
dog. You are at liberty to publish this, OF do sny
thing else with it you please. If there are any
Other facts in which was concerned generally. or
any thing more particularly relating to the melan-
choly fate Of poor Andre, sm willing and ready
at any time to attend to it, and will promptly an
swer any communication. Address to John B..
Spencer, my attorney at Livings,onville


| am, sir, respectfully yours,


DAVID WILLIAMS.
Signed in the presence OF John q. Spencer.
WILMINGTON, Del TUESDAY, FEBRUARY ", 1927

From ahe !" .,fnerpa" Of 1928.
When Hopes fairy fingers are straylng
O'er the chords of the youthful heart,
And fancy in prospects displaying
The bliss that years may imparf;
When sweet FEELINGS are ever unsprlnging,
And the pulses all joyously beat,
When each day q new treasure is brhgihgs
Oh. then indeed life is most sweet!
When the torch of affection just lighted,
burns bright or the altar Of truth,
Fre the cold. selfish world yet has blghtad
One innocent feeling Of youth.
when earth seems garden unfading,


When flowers cling around our GLAD feet'
When no cloud our bright heaven is shading,
Oh, then indeed life is most sweet.
when the cold breath Of sorrow is sweeping
O,er the chords of the youthful heart,
And the youthful eye dimmed with strange weeping.
Sees the vision Of fancy depart;
when the bloom of young feeling is dying, -
And the breast throbs With PASSIONS herce STRIFE,
When our sad days are wasted in signing,


Who then can find sweetness IN hfe
When unkindness coldEess has faded,
The pure undehled light OF love,
And the mists of the cold world have shaded
The dreams that around our hearts move;
When earth seems wide waste OF sorrow,


No longer with bright blessings rlie,
When we look but for clouds on each morrow,


who ,bSn ean 6nd sweetness in hfef ,.,,,,,
From .he /" Minerva" Of 1928.

MR. WRIGHT'S SPEECH.


Extracts from the remarks by Mr.. Wright, Of Ohio in the


U S, House of Representatives while the resolution Of


MIR Saunders, relative TO the printers OF the laws,


under consideration.


| "The gentleman, says he does not object 10 he
Jefersonisn policy ofappointing TO Office friends, and
dsmissng enemies. He would stick TO his friends
live by his friends, md If necessary, die BY his
friends. He thinks the state OF things at Mr.. JEFF
ferson,s elevation to the Presidency was entirely elf.
fcrent from what we now have and il was neces-
sary Tor him to act as he did. MIR. J. he says en-
tered into the administration with The erpress de-
sign OF so welding It's power as TO break down
proud and naughty aristocracy, who had disregard
ed the will Of the people, and had we'll nigh got their
feet upon heir cks--ha, the two parties were to-
tally different in principle, end j, was incumbent
upon MIR. ]. to consult his cabinet Tor the dismiss
sion Of those officers who opposed his sdmnisra-
tion.-Sir, if this assertion prove any thing i
shows that, in the opinion OF the gentleman, there
is nor no difference in principle between those in,
and those out oil powerful this be true, whence
arises oil this bitterness OF attack upon the men and
me asures Of the adj. nisraon, which so distinctly
marks the course o. oppostionr Does It arise from
a thirst for power and Office, or the love OF menf
After all have heard Of usurpation, and bargain,
and intrigue, such admission was net looked for.
/ Here Mr. Houston rose 20 explain, and d:scialms
ed having made any such admission.


MIR. w. proceeded. think sir, with The gen.
tleman, there is some differences OF principle, as
shall presently show. To return to Mr. Jefferson
Let il be borne in mind that that distinguished and
Iamsnted statesman and the present incumbent OF
the Presidency both to their seats by the in
tcrvention of the power Of this House.-How is il
in relation to the unprinciped and naughty afistoc-
racy? When Mr.. Jefferson took the oath, he used


in his Inaugural Address, The following emphasai
language, which recommend to the gentleman's
careful perusal Every difference o. opinion is
not a difference OF principle.-We haue called by
different names brethren Of the same principle
We are all RePublicsns--we are all Federssts"
You have here the one hand, the declarations OF
, the gentleman, who, from the nature OF things,
could only know any of the facts historically. OPP
posed to this, you have the declaration OF Mr. JET
ferson himself, openly publicly, officially made at
the time, in the presence of the assembled nation
and the world. Need it be asked which o! these


Witnesses will obtain credit to the exclusion OF the
other trust not. But. sir, the admission that
, Mr. Jefferson was called by circumstances to make
! the changes he did, admits the right. With what
discreet ii was exercised, - mere matter OF opln-
ion, and as the gentleman from N York Mr. Wcod)
remarked in the few words he said on this subje ect
{ is not within your cognzance. II We look itlc
further, however, VIC may discover, in the state of
things Immediately succeeding Mr. Jefferson's el.
ovation to the Presidency, and that following the ell
ovation Of the present inrum'en some points ofrs-
semblance, thats perhaps the gen leman did not ad
j
much indis Eliminate and coarse attack upon the


private character of Mr.. Jefferson, and upon thoss
OF the members oil his cabinet paying no regard to
the merits or demers OF his acts. cxhausling the
vocabulary Of abuse and dsgrsceful to the country
This course cisgused the people, and prosfa-


ted, forever Frustrated the party which reanFted to


it. In certain quarters, The asnc character oi bitter


and indscrimnate attack and reproach has follow


ed the elevation OF MIR. Adams and his ceoinet.--


Future events will determine whether the people
: have less sober Judgment now than then, or whek-
. er the analogy will hold good throughout Mr.. Jef~
rson disregarded these attacks and pursued steadily
, the country good He left his abuses "a monument
i of the safety with which OF opinion may be


toer ated where reason is left free to combat ir"
The present Chief Magistrate, so far as have OBJ


served pursues the same ecourse-conscious oT no.


cence and fearless of injustice from his coun'rTmen
e But, sir, contend there is now some dlHerenca


of principle between the present administrator and


its supporters, and those IN the opposition differ
. encc esteemed Of the most vital importance to ve-
: ry largs portion of the arms bearing people OF the


country. The administration maintain thai by the


principles of the Constitution, the general govern
men, has the power confer benefits on The peo-
n ple, as we'll as to impose burdens upon them-thak
has power to protect the industry OF the people
= panst the unequal competition of fosegncrs-thas
f has power to facilitate the interchange OF commo-
!, dities, and the comgeEce between tho StAses1 ~

CONDITIONS or THE WATCHMAN

NioI' FAoiS, a. klseh Ot 1o. van w art 10 MT.
1 browere, under theimpression that David Williams
was deceased. ! now place at your disposal an ac-
count as given by David Williams, The other sur
yIvor, who, to use his own words, has been stkiL-
lea three times" from which, ii you think il advise.
able you can publish some extracts, or the whole,
as you think proper.


II was not procured for publication, yet sir. as
the generous veteran has given his consent, can
hardly refrain from ring it for insertion in your
paper. Your. respectfully.


Jan. 3lst, 1897.


=. ..s As to The narrative you request,
cannot materially add TO the already given
by my cOmrade and cousin, Col. Van Wart.
can tell II little more fully, and you spress
wish TO know it, will give it mnutely. The fol,
lowing is correct account:


The transactions are as fresh in my recoec-
ton at this day they were the hour that unio,,u
nate and elegant man upon the scsfod to render
up his life in expiaoD to the injured laws OF
infant country. 1t is great error, which find
most people have adopted that Paudlng, Van Wart
and myself, were OF the regular army-such is not
the iact. We were neither OF as enlisted soldiers,
but had at oil times volunteered and at different
times were engaged in skirmishes-pltched battles
we're not much in fashion at that day--and our glo
rious commander understood and valued too much


the interest Of his country to risk his small army
against the united forces Of British and tories
Thus at all times from the year 75 to the year 80
wr were kind OF standing corps OF yoluneers.-
4 When an alarm was given, we went At the time
referred to by Col. Van Wsrt, We were out Of
business" and having heard that tories, refugees,
BIC. frequently passed to the enemy with cattle,
left our homes OF our own accord, which was TWEEN
" miles from Tarytown, between two and three
O'Clock in the afternoon, with guns. seven Of US
in company, to wit, John Paulding, Isaac Van
Wart, John Yerks, William Williams William
Pauding, (brother to John,) James Romer, and
my self. And let it be expressly understood that
this expedition was Of our own panning and that
we at that time under the command oi no per-
s9n whatever. We travelled together as tar as
John Anderson's, fifteen miles from where start
cd at which place arrived at about nine or ten
O'Clock in the evening--that night we slept IN his
hay barrack. In the morning we LEFT our lodging
and procee eded towards Tsryytown AT Davis Hill,
Psuld,ng Vsn Wart, and myself, agreed to 60 near
Tarrytown, and lie in wait while the other four stad
at Davis Hill to watch, as the road parts at that
place. We therefore proceeded, and at the
!" White Wood Tree" half mile north OF Tarry-
a town. we stopped, and having previously procured
j, pack OF cards. we went into the bushes abou,
twenty rods from the said "tree," and commenc-
cd playing cards. While playing. number o


people pasxed whom we knew and oil course did
not molest. | should think i, not more than
three quarters of an hour alter We had seated our


selves and though, search fruitless. before we
heard a horse pass the small bridge about fifteen
Il rods from where we were. at brisk pace. Either
! y Paudinp or Van Wsrt, I do not recollect which
:, said /" here comes trader Upon this sprana
e up and resumed our arms and stopped hint
L was Andre on horseback. He accosted US in this
n way, My lads, hope you belong to our party
We asked which psrtyp'' He said the lower
n party.'' We said We do" He then said, " am
n British officer, have been in the country on par


,icuar business, and would not wish to be detained
= = a moment; and token to let you know that
d am gentleman here is my gold watch which hs


showed, and an elegant one it was We then told
af him we were Americans. He replied, God bies
y nv soul, man must do any thing now.n days
7 FL then pulled out pass from Arnold We toll
Of him that would enable him TO pass, as he was
i prisoner and must dismount. We then took hin
,e down in the bushes, about 20 rods, and was tn
nne appointed 10 search, while the other two tool


care the one OF his horse, and the other az guard


| commenced my search by taking on his hat, mex


his coat and vest, and then his small clothes, ant
= found nothing. To all Of this he quietly submit
ted. then told him he must sit down and wou


take off his boots. pulled of his boot, and as i


came of, Pauldng said " here 'tis." do not re


collect that at this time, he changed countenance


all, or showed the least symptoms oi iear-his Who'll


conduct was that OF gentleman. tie then said


now you've got all" We then told him TO drcs
and go with us-he did--we took him across th


road towards Davis hill-wc had gone something
like ten rods, when asked him where he go


those papers he said he got them at Lines bridge


Of q man." We asked him who the man was


He said he did not know. He then made US offers


he told us if we would let him 60, he would Civ


vs. one thousand guineas, his horse, saddle and brl


N. Our answer is known, He then told US. h


would give US ten thousand guneas, and as man.


dry goods as we would name, and to make 1t sur


we might deposi'e him as hostage in any piac


we pleased, until the goods and gold were delivers
From the Nelo Fork Times.

IHE CASE OF MORGAN we do not learn that
any additional facts have been brought to gh, since
our last publication upon this subject, although
rcpor, has obtained circulation in many Of the pa
pers that the body Of Morgan has been found in
manged condition. under the falls Of Niagara. But
this is not true. At this season OF the year, no hu
man being can get TO the place where the body was
said to be found.


While upon this subject, we cannot but express
our regret, that the Editors OF the N. Y. Gazette
should have admitted the communication into their
columns which appears this morning under the
signature Of T" Hiram.' One OF the Editors OF The
Gazette, land We know not but more,) is mason.
and the publication, by him, of a abored article,
palliang il not entirely excusing, the guilt OF those
concerned in Morgan's abduction, will have a ten
dency to injure the craft, notwithstanding The edi


orial disclaimer OF the lengths TO which Master
Hiram goes. They could not do less, for whether
murdered or not Hiram would excuse the aggres
sors. And not only Hiram, but We are concerned
TO say that some young gentlemen OF the order
have created no little i'll blood among those who are
| not masons by holding similar language. In con
sequence OF such declarations, We have been called
upon by respectable gentlemen, and gravely ask
ed, whether the principles OF our order compel US
to keep The secrets ol murderer We answer, No !!
| We are unquestionatly bound to keep The secrets
OF our worthy" brethren, when committed to US
as such, 10 certain extent But in our most sol
| tmn obligations, +" murder" is among the express
exceptions. Away then, with these sckly attempts
to extenua,s the conduct Of The aggresnors in this
affair. Be he Dead or be he living, there is no ma
sonic excuse for the violation of the civil law. ii
he is living, let the masonic fanatics who carried
him off, make ii maniest-produce him, II he is
within their power or prove the fact If he is in q
plot keep out of the view until his fortune is made
by his book. But If he has been put to death, let
none "lay the fatterng JUNCTION 10 their souls,
that his blood is not in their skirts. What though
he had proved recreant to his principles and solat.
cd his oath to preserve the secrets Of his order shall
a band Of men, in a moment Of indignation, dcliber
ateiy put 10 death fellow being, who for the same
offence made out legally against the state. would
only be consigned to the state prison? II cannot be,
and every mason should set his face against such
monstrous opinions. We repeat il, member OF
the masonic fraternity. that if Morgan has been put
10 death Cod forbid that it should prove so }
his blood cries from the ground for vengeance, as
loud as did tho blood of Abel


i 1t will be seen, by the following Proclamation o
Sir Peregrine Maitland, Governor OF the Province
OF Upper Canada, that reward Of Two Hundred


Dollars is offered for the recovery Of Morgan
i TWO HUNDRED DOLLARS REWARD.
a His Excelency the Lieut.. Governor, having re
ceiyed communication from His Excelicnry, The


Governor of the State Of New York, by which i, ap


pears that WILLIAM MORGAN, who soms
years ago. exercised the calling Of brewer in th
place, and who has subsequently resided at Cananda


qua, in the state Of New York, was some time ir


the last year. conveyed by force from that pace,ant
is supposed be foreiby detained, under false pre-


tences in some part of this Province, any person
who may be able to afford any information respect
ing the said William Morgan, shall, upon commu


nicaling the same. to the private Secretary OF His
! Excellency, the Lieut.. Governor. receive the re
ward above offered.


Government House, Jan. 31st, 1927.
Of very excellent quality-.for sale at His 1Jtc'

full articles.article:
The committee appointed by the resolution os,he
Grand Chapter, on the affair OF William Morgan,
respectfully report:


That they have attended to the duties assigned
them, and from the highly agtated and in6amed
state of public feeling this subject, and from the
false and undeservcd imputstiops which have been
thrown upon freemasons. and the masonic order
generally your committee deem it proper that this
Grand Chapter should make public expression of
its sentiments in relation to the affair alluded TO.
Your committee, as expressive of their views on this
subject, would offer for the consideration of the
Grand Chapter, the following preamble and resolu-
ton.


Whereas. the rights ofpersona liberty and secu-
rity are guaranteed by the free contribution under
which we, the members Of this Grand Chapter, in
common with the rest Of our fellow citizens, have
the happiness to live: And whereas we esteem the
preservation Of these rights Of vital importanee 70
The perpetuity and full enjoyment Of the blessings

full articles.headline: y Wilson, No. 1O5, Market Street.
full articles.article:
our republican institutions - Ard whereas the COM
munty has lately Witnessed a violation Of the same
under the alleged pretext of the masonic name and
sanction, in the case Of William Morgan: And
whereas the principles of our ancient and honorable
fraternity contain nothing which in the slightest de-
gree justify or authorize such proceedings but,
on the contrary, do in all their tenets and cereno-
nies, encourages and inculcate just submission to
the laws, the enjoyment Of equal rights by every
individual, and high and elevated spirit OF person.
al as well as national independence:


Therefore Resolred, by this Grand Chapter, that
we its members, individually and body, do
dscaim all knowledge or appreciation Of the said
proceedings. in relation to the abduction OF the said
William Morgan and that we disapprove Of he
same violation Of the majesty Of the laws, and
infringement, Of the rights Of personal liberty,
cured every citizen Of our free and happy repub-
lie.


A true extract from the minutes the Grand
Royal Arch Chapter the state of New.fork.


]. o. COLE, .sec'ry

full articles.headline: WILMINGTON, Del TUESDAY, FEBRUARY ", 1927
full articles.article:
John Anderson-we supposed it was. He then
addressed a letter to Gen Washington, in which
he declared his name and rank-it was John Andre,
Of the rank of major, acting adjutant general to the
British army. The fate Of the poor fellow is ell
known--I saw him executed. have frequently
heard it said he agiated, hc.-t is not correct,
at least Tar as il could be seen. He met his death
like q man, and died like soldier, the death Of a
dog. You are at liberty to publish this, OF do sny
thing else with it you please. If there are any
Other facts in which was concerned generally. or
any thing more particularly relating to the melan-
choly fate Of poor Andre, sm willing and ready
at any time to attend to it, and will promptly an
swer any communication. Address to John B..
Spencer, my attorney at Livings,onville


| am, sir, respectfully yours,


DAVID WILLIAMS.
Signed in the presence OF John q. Spencer.

full articles.headline: From .he /" Minerva" Of 1928.
full articles.article:
From ahe !" .,fnerpa" Of 1928.
When Hopes fairy fingers are straylng
O'er the chords of the youthful heart,
And fancy in prospects displaying
The bliss that years may imparf;
When sweet FEELINGS are ever unsprlnging,
And the pulses all joyously beat,
When each day q new treasure is brhgihgs
Oh. then indeed life is most sweet!
When the torch of affection just lighted,
burns bright or the altar Of truth,
Fre the cold. selfish world yet has blghtad
One innocent feeling Of youth.
when earth seems garden unfading,


When flowers cling around our GLAD feet'
When no cloud our bright heaven is shading,
Oh, then indeed life is most sweet.
when the cold breath Of sorrow is sweeping
O,er the chords of the youthful heart,
And the youthful eye dimmed with strange weeping.
Sees the vision Of fancy depart;
when the bloom of young feeling is dying, -
And the breast throbs With PASSIONS herce STRIFE,
When our sad days are wasted in signing,


Who then can find sweetness IN hfe
When unkindness coldEess has faded,
The pure undehled light OF love,
And the mists of the cold world have shaded
The dreams that around our hearts move;
When earth seems wide waste OF sorrow,


No longer with bright blessings rlie,
When we look but for clouds on each morrow,


who ,bSn ean 6nd sweetness in hfef ,.,,,,,

full articles.headline: MIR. WRIGHT,S SPEECH.
full articles.article:
MR. WRIGHT'S SPEECH.


Extracts from the remarks by Mr.. Wright, Of Ohio in the


U S, House of Representatives while the resolution Of


MIR Saunders, relative TO the printers OF the laws,


under consideration.


| "The gentleman, says he does not object 10 he
Jefersonisn policy ofappointing TO Office friends, and
dsmissng enemies. He would stick TO his friends
live by his friends, md If necessary, die BY his
friends. He thinks the state OF things at Mr.. JEFF
ferson,s elevation to the Presidency was entirely elf.
fcrent from what we now have and il was neces-
sary Tor him to act as he did. MIR. J. he says en-
tered into the administration with The erpress de-
sign OF so welding It's power as TO break down
proud and naughty aristocracy, who had disregard
ed the will Of the people, and had we'll nigh got their
feet upon heir cks--ha, the two parties were to-
tally different in principle, end j, was incumbent
upon MIR. ]. to consult his cabinet Tor the dismiss
sion Of those officers who opposed his sdmnisra-
tion.-Sir, if this assertion prove any thing i
shows that, in the opinion OF the gentleman, there
is nor no difference in principle between those in,
and those out oil powerful this be true, whence
arises oil this bitterness OF attack upon the men and
me asures Of the adj. nisraon, which so distinctly
marks the course o. oppostionr Does It arise from
a thirst for power and Office, or the love OF menf
After all have heard Of usurpation, and bargain,
and intrigue, such admission was net looked for.
/ Here Mr. Houston rose 20 explain, and d:scialms
ed having made any such admission.


MIR. w. proceeded. think sir, with The gen.
tleman, there is some differences OF principle, as
shall presently show. To return to Mr. Jefferson
Let il be borne in mind that that distinguished and
Iamsnted statesman and the present incumbent OF
the Presidency both to their seats by the in
tcrvention of the power Of this House.-How is il
in relation to the unprinciped and naughty afistoc-
racy? When Mr.. Jefferson took the oath, he used


in his Inaugural Address, The following emphasai
language, which recommend to the gentleman's
careful perusal Every difference o. opinion is
not a difference OF principle.-We haue called by
different names brethren Of the same principle
We are all RePublicsns--we are all Federssts"
You have here the one hand, the declarations OF
, the gentleman, who, from the nature OF things,
could only know any of the facts historically. OPP
posed to this, you have the declaration OF Mr. JET
ferson himself, openly publicly, officially made at
the time, in the presence of the assembled nation
and the world. Need it be asked which o! these


Witnesses will obtain credit to the exclusion OF the
other trust not. But. sir, the admission that
, Mr. Jefferson was called by circumstances to make
! the changes he did, admits the right. With what
discreet ii was exercised, - mere matter OF opln-
ion, and as the gentleman from N York Mr. Wcod)
remarked in the few words he said on this subje ect
{ is not within your cognzance. II We look itlc
further, however, VIC may discover, in the state of
things Immediately succeeding Mr. Jefferson's el.
ovation to the Presidency, and that following the ell
ovation Of the present inrum'en some points ofrs-
semblance, thats perhaps the gen leman did not ad
j
much indis Eliminate and coarse attack upon the


private character of Mr.. Jefferson, and upon thoss
OF the members oil his cabinet paying no regard to
the merits or demers OF his acts. cxhausling the
vocabulary Of abuse and dsgrsceful to the country
This course cisgused the people, and prosfa-


ted, forever Frustrated the party which reanFted to


it. In certain quarters, The asnc character oi bitter


and indscrimnate attack and reproach has follow


ed the elevation OF MIR. Adams and his ceoinet.--


Future events will determine whether the people
: have less sober Judgment now than then, or whek-
. er the analogy will hold good throughout Mr.. Jef~
rson disregarded these attacks and pursued steadily
, the country good He left his abuses "a monument
i of the safety with which OF opinion may be


toer ated where reason is left free to combat ir"
The present Chief Magistrate, so far as have OBJ


served pursues the same ecourse-conscious oT no.


cence and fearless of injustice from his coun'rTmen
e But, sir, contend there is now some dlHerenca


of principle between the present administrator and


its supporters, and those IN the opposition differ
. encc esteemed Of the most vital importance to ve-
: ry largs portion of the arms bearing people OF the


country. The administration maintain thai by the


principles of the Constitution, the general govern
men, has the power confer benefits on The peo-
n ple, as we'll as to impose burdens upon them-thak
has power to protect the industry OF the people
= panst the unequal competition of fosegncrs-thas
f has power to facilitate the interchange OF commo-
!, dities, and the comgeEce between tho StAses1 ~

full articles.headline: From the Nelo Fork Times.
full articles.article:
NioI' FAoiS, a. klseh Ot 1o. van w art 10 MT.
1 browere, under theimpression that David Williams
was deceased. ! now place at your disposal an ac-
count as given by David Williams, The other sur
yIvor, who, to use his own words, has been stkiL-
lea three times" from which, ii you think il advise.
able you can publish some extracts, or the whole,
as you think proper.


II was not procured for publication, yet sir. as
the generous veteran has given his consent, can
hardly refrain from ring it for insertion in your
paper. Your. respectfully.


Jan. 3lst, 1897.


=. ..s As to The narrative you request,
cannot materially add TO the already given
by my cOmrade and cousin, Col. Van Wart.
can tell II little more fully, and you spress
wish TO know it, will give it mnutely. The fol,
lowing is correct account:


The transactions are as fresh in my recoec-
ton at this day they were the hour that unio,,u
nate and elegant man upon the scsfod to render
up his life in expiaoD to the injured laws OF
infant country. 1t is great error, which find
most people have adopted that Paudlng, Van Wart
and myself, were OF the regular army-such is not
the iact. We were neither OF as enlisted soldiers,
but had at oil times volunteered and at different
times were engaged in skirmishes-pltched battles
we're not much in fashion at that day--and our glo
rious commander understood and valued too much


the interest Of his country to risk his small army
against the united forces Of British and tories
Thus at all times from the year 75 to the year 80
wr were kind OF standing corps OF yoluneers.-
4 When an alarm was given, we went At the time
referred to by Col. Van Wsrt, We were out Of
business" and having heard that tories, refugees,
BIC. frequently passed to the enemy with cattle,
left our homes OF our own accord, which was TWEEN
" miles from Tarytown, between two and three
O'Clock in the afternoon, with guns. seven Of US
in company, to wit, John Paulding, Isaac Van
Wart, John Yerks, William Williams William
Pauding, (brother to John,) James Romer, and
my self. And let it be expressly understood that
this expedition was Of our own panning and that
we at that time under the command oi no per-
s9n whatever. We travelled together as tar as
John Anderson's, fifteen miles from where start
cd at which place arrived at about nine or ten
O'Clock in the evening--that night we slept IN his
hay barrack. In the morning we LEFT our lodging
and procee eded towards Tsryytown AT Davis Hill,
Psuld,ng Vsn Wart, and myself, agreed to 60 near
Tarrytown, and lie in wait while the other four stad
at Davis Hill to watch, as the road parts at that
place. We therefore proceeded, and at the
!" White Wood Tree" half mile north OF Tarry-
a town. we stopped, and having previously procured
j, pack OF cards. we went into the bushes abou,
twenty rods from the said "tree," and commenc-
cd playing cards. While playing. number o


people pasxed whom we knew and oil course did
not molest. | should think i, not more than
three quarters of an hour alter We had seated our


selves and though, search fruitless. before we
heard a horse pass the small bridge about fifteen
Il rods from where we were. at brisk pace. Either
! y Paudinp or Van Wsrt, I do not recollect which
:, said /" here comes trader Upon this sprana
e up and resumed our arms and stopped hint
L was Andre on horseback. He accosted US in this
n way, My lads, hope you belong to our party
We asked which psrtyp'' He said the lower
n party.'' We said We do" He then said, " am
n British officer, have been in the country on par


,icuar business, and would not wish to be detained
= = a moment; and token to let you know that
d am gentleman here is my gold watch which hs


showed, and an elegant one it was We then told
af him we were Americans. He replied, God bies
y nv soul, man must do any thing now.n days
7 FL then pulled out pass from Arnold We toll
Of him that would enable him TO pass, as he was
i prisoner and must dismount. We then took hin
,e down in the bushes, about 20 rods, and was tn
nne appointed 10 search, while the other two tool


care the one OF his horse, and the other az guard


| commenced my search by taking on his hat, mex


his coat and vest, and then his small clothes, ant
= found nothing. To all Of this he quietly submit
ted. then told him he must sit down and wou


take off his boots. pulled of his boot, and as i


came of, Pauldng said " here 'tis." do not re


collect that at this time, he changed countenance


all, or showed the least symptoms oi iear-his Who'll


conduct was that OF gentleman. tie then said


now you've got all" We then told him TO drcs
and go with us-he did--we took him across th


road towards Davis hill-wc had gone something
like ten rods, when asked him where he go


those papers he said he got them at Lines bridge


Of q man." We asked him who the man was


He said he did not know. He then made US offers


he told us if we would let him 60, he would Civ


vs. one thousand guineas, his horse, saddle and brl


N. Our answer is known, He then told US. h


would give US ten thousand guneas, and as man.


dry goods as we would name, and to make 1t sur


we might deposi'e him as hostage in any piac


we pleased, until the goods and gold were delivers

IHE CASE OF MORGAN we do not learn that
any additional facts have been brought to gh, since
our last publication upon this subject, although
rcpor, has obtained circulation in many Of the pa
pers that the body Of Morgan has been found in
manged condition. under the falls Of Niagara. But
this is not true. At this season OF the year, no hu
man being can get TO the place where the body was
said to be found.


While upon this subject, we cannot but express
our regret, that the Editors OF the N. Y. Gazette
should have admitted the communication into their
columns which appears this morning under the
signature Of T" Hiram.' One OF the Editors OF The
Gazette, land We know not but more,) is mason.
and the publication, by him, of a abored article,
palliang il not entirely excusing, the guilt OF those
concerned in Morgan's abduction, will have a ten
dency to injure the craft, notwithstanding The edi


orial disclaimer OF the lengths TO which Master
Hiram goes. They could not do less, for whether
murdered or not Hiram would excuse the aggres
sors. And not only Hiram, but We are concerned
TO say that some young gentlemen OF the order
have created no little i'll blood among those who are
| not masons by holding similar language. In con
sequence OF such declarations, We have been called
upon by respectable gentlemen, and gravely ask
ed, whether the principles OF our order compel US
to keep The secrets ol murderer We answer, No !!
| We are unquestionatly bound to keep The secrets
OF our worthy" brethren, when committed to US
as such, 10 certain extent But in our most sol
| tmn obligations, +" murder" is among the express
exceptions. Away then, with these sckly attempts
to extenua,s the conduct Of The aggresnors in this
affair. Be he Dead or be he living, there is no ma
sonic excuse for the violation of the civil law. ii
he is living, let the masonic fanatics who carried
him off, make ii maniest-produce him, II he is
within their power or prove the fact If he is in q
plot keep out of the view until his fortune is made
by his book. But If he has been put to death, let
none "lay the fatterng JUNCTION 10 their souls,
that his blood is not in their skirts. What though
he had proved recreant to his principles and solat.
cd his oath to preserve the secrets Of his order shall
a band Of men, in a moment Of indignation, dcliber
ateiy put 10 death fellow being, who for the same
offence made out legally against the state. would
only be consigned to the state prison? II cannot be,
and every mason should set his face against such
monstrous opinions. We repeat il, member OF
the masonic fraternity. that if Morgan has been put
10 death Cod forbid that it should prove so }
his blood cries from the ground for vengeance, as
loud as did tho blood of Abel


i 1t will be seen, by the following Proclamation o
Sir Peregrine Maitland, Governor OF the Province
OF Upper Canada, that reward Of Two Hundred


Dollars is offered for the recovery Of Morgan
i TWO HUNDRED DOLLARS REWARD.
a His Excelency the Lieut.. Governor, having re
ceiyed communication from His Excelicnry, The


Governor of the State Of New York, by which i, ap


pears that WILLIAM MORGAN, who soms
years ago. exercised the calling Of brewer in th
place, and who has subsequently resided at Cananda


qua, in the state Of New York, was some time ir


the last year. conveyed by force from that pace,ant
is supposed be foreiby detained, under false pre-


tences in some part of this Province, any person
who may be able to afford any information respect
ing the said William Morgan, shall, upon commu


nicaling the same. to the private Secretary OF His
! Excellency, the Lieut.. Governor. receive the re
ward above offered.


Government House, Jan. 31st, 1927.
